body_html:
This error message is returned when you attempt to use -1 as a "wildcard dimension" in a call to tf.reshape().

For example:

c = tf.random_uniform([4, 4])
d = tf.reshape(c, [2, -1])
print d.shape  # (2, 8)

However, when a tensor is empty (i.e. it has 0 elements), there is more than one possible value for the wildcard to take:

c = tf.random_uniform([4, 0])
d = tf.reshape(c, [0, -1])
print d.shape  # Could be (0, 0), (0, 1), (0, 2), ...

The only exception to this case is when the wildcard dimension must evaluate to 0. This will be the case if the number of input elements is 0, and all the specified dimensions for the new shape are non-zero:

c = tf.random_uniform([4, 0])
d = tf.reshape(c, [37, -1])
print d.shape  # (37, 0)

Hope this makes sense!

print d.shape  # (37, 0)
Hope this makes sense!
body:
This error message is returned when you attempt to use `-1` as a "wildcard dimension" in a call to `tf.reshape()`.

For example:

```python
c = tf.random_uniform([4, 4])
d = tf.reshape(c, [2, -1])
print d.shape  # (2, 8)
```

However, when a tensor is empty (i.e. it has 0 elements), there is more than one possible value for the wildcard to take:

```python
c = tf.random_uniform([4, 0])
d = tf.reshape(c, [0, -1])
print d.shape  # Could be (0, 0), (0, 1), (0, 2), ...
```

The only exception to this case is when the wildcard dimension must evaluate to 0. This will be the case if the number of input elements is 0, and all the specified dimensions for the new shape are non-zero:

```python
c = tf.random_uniform([4, 0])
d = tf.reshape(c, [37, -1])
print d.shape  # (37, 0)
```

Hope this makes sense!
